results.title: More Than Just a Game
results.material_description: Videogame, arcade machine handcrafted from reclaimed Australian blackwood, LED lettering, custom flooring
results.brief_description:
“Just like in the arcade games of the past, the government initiatives that exist are currently about us, without us. I want us to be seen, to have a say that enables us to take back control.”

Jarra Karalinar Steel conjures the nostalgic excitement of 1990s videogame arcades in More Than Just a Game. At its centre is The Adventures of Dolly, a playable game made with Wiradjuri and Ngiyampaa illustrator Charlotte Allingham. Take the controls and take Dolly on a journey through an alternate reality or not-so-distant future of Melbourne’s CBD, featuring iconic trams and Swanston Street.Growing up, videogame protagonists weren’t relatable to Jarra.

This work remedies that, giving First Peoples a chance to see ourselves imagined in a videogame – made for us, by us. Through The Adventures of Dolly, custom possum and wallaby spirit flooring and the hand-carved arcade cabinet, Jarra reclaims a place that hasn’t reflected our experiences. She brings Indigenous stories into gaming, inspiring the next generation and giving us power to determine our own futures.

constellations_primary.name: Indigenous futurisms
constellations_primary.description: An exploration of works that put First Peoples futurisms first.

constellations_other.name: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
constellations_other.description: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls explores the reality of living in Mparntwe (Alice Springs) through the eyes of the artists, who grew up there. Place and Indigenous representation are also vital to the other works in this Constellation.

Game designed in collaboration with Charlotte Allingham

Game programmed by Peter Russell Adams

Arcade cabinet made with assistance from David Brophy

results.title: Corroboree
results.brief_description: ‘Corroboree’ is both a record of the world premiere of the famous Australian ballet, and a behind-the-scenes glimpse of the rehearsal, design and preparation that went into the production. Inspired by composer John Antill’s best known work, the ballet was sponsored by the Arts Council of Australia and choreographed by Rex Reid. Performed by the National Theatre Ballet Company and the Sydney Symphony Orchestra, ‘Corroboree’ is a striking illustration of some of the ways in which white Australia has imagined and expropriated Australian First Nations cultures.

results.title: Wildcats and Pipedreams
results.creator_credit: David Greig, John Richardson and Kestrel Film & Television
results.brief_description: Wildcats and Pipedreams follows the crew of an oil drilling rig in the Timor Sea. It gives a fascinating insight into the lives of people living and working in a remote and difficult environment.

results.title: Minyak Sawit Keluarga (Palm Oil Family)
results.brief_description: Minyak Sawit Keluarga (Palm Oil Family) by artist Olivia Koh, examines her paternal family’s history of farming practices in rural Southern Malaysia (Peninsula). Footage of domestic-scale palm oil plantations in Johor is interspersed with visual and auditory recordings of funerary Daoist rituals, documents and interviews that consider the palm oil industry and relevant history of migration in the local area.
results.description: Minyak Sawit Keluarga (Palm Oil Family) by artist Olivia Koh, examines her paternal family’s history of farming practices in rural Southern Malaysia (Peninsula). results.title: The Dark Current
results.credit_line:
Ian Potter Moving Image Commission
ACMI Collection
Courtesy the artist and Sullivan + Strumpf, Sydney
results.brief_description:
“The Dark Current has a specific shape to it, that reaches for the essence of a multi-generational experience. One that starts with my mother’s generation, through to mine and on to our children.” Angela Tiatia, 2023

The Dark Current was conceived as a “dream-like visual poem” in three parts that represent the past, present and future. The artwork opens with a striking close-up of a glamorous woman with a pearl in her eye, who is slowly engulfed by water. The artist considers this scene an allegory of the promise that lured her mother’s generation to migrate from the Pacific Islands to countries like New Zealand and Australia in the 1960s.

The middle section weaves together choreographed performances filmed in a production studio with footage of Pacific Island landscapes. It seeks to capture the dark and chaotic feeling of the current moment, as the climate emergency and rising sea levels wreak catastrophic damage across the Pacific Islands and global south.

The final scene is created with software more commonly used to develop videogames. This hyper realistic world is filled with towering ice monuments set atop colourful disco flooring and populated by a cast of performers dressed in pink. The artist describes this joyful vision of the future as “a space of cultural self-actualisation and celebration.”

The Dark Current reflects how we no longer think of the physical and the virtual as being separate spaces, while celebrating Tiatia’s connection to her family history and Sāmoan culture.

Angela Tiatia is a Sāmoan and Australian artist who lives and works in Sydney. She works primarily with moving image and performance to explore contemporary culture, in particular the relationships between representation, gender, neo-colonialism and the commodification of body and place. Tiatia’s work has been exhibited nationally and internationally, and her work is held in private and public collections including Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa; Art Gallery of New South Wales, Sydney; Museum of Contemporary Art, Sydney; National Gallery of Victoria, Melbourne; and Queensland Art Gallery | Gallery of Modern Art, Brisbane.

constellations_primary.name: Pink subversions
constellations_primary.description: Pink dominates Angela Tiatia's The Dark Current. The artist describes this particular colour as “artificial”, “unapologetic” and “pulsating with feminine energy”. In Tiatia's Sāmoan heritage “there is a brashness in the use of colour. I really wanted to embody that.”

results.title: The Simpsons arcade cabinet
results.brief_description: The Simpsons arcade game set itself apart from other brawlers and TV game properties with the show’s main cast voicing the characters, who have unique weapons to swing at enemies. Unfortunately, Lee Carvallo isn’t in the game so you can’t use a three-wood golf club.
results.description:
The Simpsons had only screened one season when Konami released this side-scrolling beat em up in 1991. It wasn’t that Konami knew how successful The Simpsons would be, it’s that they already had the foundation for the game. Two years earlier they’d developed the Teenage Mutant Nina Turtles arcade game and applied the same mechanics to The Simpsons, which featured almost identical play style and button mashing combat. What set The Simpsons apart was the accurate voice renditions, with the TV show’s main cast voicing the characters in the game.

Players can control either Homer, Marge, Bart or Lisa as they use unique fighting techniques – punching or swinging a vacuum cleaner, skateboard or skipping rope – to rescue Maggie after she’s kidnapped by Smithers.

Unfortunately, Lee Carvallo isn’t in the game so you can’t swing a three-wood golf club.
description_for_label:
The Simpsons had only been on-air for one season when Konami released this four-player side-scrolling ‘beat em up’ in 1991. It wasn’t that Konami knew what a phenomenon The Simpsons would become, it’s that they already had the blueprints for the game. Two years earlier they’d developed the successful Teenage Mutant Nina Turtles arcade game and applied the same mechanics to The Simpsons, which featured almost identical play style and two-button combat.

What set The Simpsons apart was the accurate voice renditions of everyone’s favourite Springfield residents, with the TV show’s main cast voicing the characters in the game. Players control either Homer, Marge, Bart or Lisa as they use unique fighting techniques – punching, swinging a vacuum cleaner, skateboard or skipping rope – to rescue Maggie after she’s kidnapped by Smithers. Unfortunately, Lee Carvallo isn’t in the game so you can’t swing a three-wood golf club.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Games Lab → GL-02. Cluster 2 → GL-02-C01

results.title: Basketball arcade cabinet
results.brief_description: Before NBA Jam, there was Atari’s Basketball. Released just in time for the arcade heyday of the early 1980s, it was the first basketball game to use a trackball controller and a 45-degree angled side view.

constellations_primary.name: Atari’s Basketball
constellations_primary.description: Released in 1979, just in time for the arcade heydays of the early 1980s, Atari’s Basketball was the first basketball game to use a trackball as the input mechanic and a 45-degree angled side view. This set the standard for basketball games that followed.

results.description: Before NBA Jam and the NBA 2K basketball series, there was Atari’s Basketball. Released in 1979, just in time for the arcade heydays of the early 1980s, it was the first basketball game to use a trackball as the input mechanic and a 45-degree angled side view. Not only did this become part of the playbook for basketball games that followed, but Basketball was also the first sports game where the pixelated sprites players controlled actually looked like people. The game unit’s neon graphic design is also uniquely of its time and reflects the burgeoning videogame aesthetic.
description_for_label: Before NBA Jam and the NBA 2K basketball series, there was Atari’s Basketball. Released in 1979, just in time for the arcade heydays of the early 1980s, it was the first basketball game to use a trackball as the input mechanic and a 45-degree angled side view. Not only did this become part of the playbook for basketball games that followed, but Basketball was also the first sports game where the pixelated sprites players controlled actually looked like people. The game unit’s neon graphic design is also uniquely of its time and reflects the burgeoning videogame aesthetic.

results.title: BabaKiueria
results.creator_credit: Don Featherstone, Julian Pringle, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Geoffrey Atherden
results.brief_description:
‘BabaKiueria’ takes a satirical look at black-white relations in late twentieth century Australia, with a comic depiction of a racial role reversal. In documentary (or ‘mockumentary’) style, the film’s presenter investigates white lives in the fictitious land of ‘BabaKiueria’ (‘Barbeque Area’), where white people are a minority, living under black laws and suffering from discriminatory practices and attitudes held by the black majority. Written by Geoffrey Atherden (‘Mother and Son’, ‘Grass Roots’), the film was awarded a United Nations Media Peace Prize in 1987.
Stars Michelle Torres, Bob Maza, Kevin Smith, Cecily Polson, Tony Barry.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Featherstone, Julian Pringle, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Geoffrey Atherden

results.title: Green Fingers: Looking After Lemons
results.brief_description:
‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Looking After Lemons’, gardener Rod Cantrill shows ways to look after the popular lemon tree.

The narrator points out various issues that can afflict them including collar rot, leaf yellowing, leaf fall, and pests and diseases, while Cantrill works on lemon trees in a beautiful orchard. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Green Fingers: Indoor Plants
results.brief_description:
‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Indoor Plants’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to propagate and look after indoor plants.

The film contains wonderful footage of the glasshouses at Burnley Horticultural College, with plants shown including rubber plants, philodendron and rex begonias. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.
